an6.1:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an6.1:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
an6.1:2.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant with six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an6.1:2.3: It’s a mendicant who, when they see a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
an6.1:2.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
an6.1:2.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
an6.1:2.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
an6.1:2.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
an6.1:2.8: When they know a thought with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
an6.1:2.9: A mendicant with these six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
an6.1:3.1: That is what the Buddha said.
an6.1:3.2: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
